abstract_sentences.1: Knowledge bases are important resources for a variety of natural language processing tasks but suffer from incompleteness.
abstract_sentences.2: We propose a novel embedding model, ITransF, to perform knowledge base completion.
abstract_sentences.3: Equipped with a sparse attention mechanism, ITransF discovers hidden concepts of relations and transfer statistical strength through the sharing of concepts.
abstract_sentences.4: Moreover, the learned associations between relations and concepts, which are represented by sparse attention vectors, can be interpreted easily.
abstract_sentences.5: We evaluate ITransF on two benchmark datasets— WN18 and FB15k for knowledge base completion and obtains improvements on both the mean rank and Hits@10 metrics, over all baselines that do not use additional information.

https://doi.org/10.18653/v1/P17-1088  1 Introduction  Knowledge bases (KB), such as WordNet (Fellbaum, 1998), Freebase (Bollacker et al., 2008), YAGO (Suchanek et al., 2007) and DBpedia (Lehmann et al., 2015), are useful resources for many applications such as question answering (Berant et al., 2013; Yih et al., 2015; Dai et al., 2016) and information extraction (Mintz et al., 2009).
body_sentences.2: However, knowledge bases suffer from incompleteness despite their formidable sizes (Socher et al., 2013; West et al., 2014), leading to a number of studies on automatic knowledge base completion (KBC) (Nickel et al., 2015) or link prediction.
body_sentences.3: The fundamental motivation behind these studies is that there exist some statistical regularities under the intertwined facts stored in the multirelational knowledge base.
body_sentences.4:
By discovering gener-
alizable regularities in known facts, missing ones may be recovered in a faithful way.
body_sentences.5: Due to its excellent generalization capability, distributed representations, a.k.a.
body_sentences.6: embeddings, have been popularized to address the KBC task (Nickel et al., 2011; Bordes et al., 2011, 2014, 2013; Socher et al., 2013; Wang et al., 2014; Guu et al., 2015; Nguyen et al., 2016b).
body_sentences.7: As a seminal work, Bordes et al.
body_sentences.8: (2013) proposes the TransE, which models the statistical regularities with linear translations between entity embeddings operated by a relation embedding.
body_sentences.9: Implicitly, TransE assumes both entity embeddings and relation embeddings dwell in the same vector space, posing an unnecessarily strong prior.
body_sentences.10: To relax this requirement, a variety of models first project the entity embeddings to a relationdependent space (Bordes et al., 2014; Ji et al., 2015; Lin et al., 2015b; Nguyen et al., 2016b), and then model the translation property in the projected space.
body_sentences.11: Typically, these relation-dependent spaces are characterized by the projection matrices unique to each relation.
body_sentences.12: As a benefit, different aspects of the same entity can be temporarily emphasized or depressed as an effect of the projection.
body_sentences.13: For instance, STransE (Nguyen et al., 2016b) utilizes two projection matrices per relation, one for the head entity and the other for the tail entity.
body_sentences.14: Despite the superior performance of STransE compared to TransE, it is more prone to the data sparsity problem.
body_sentences.15: Concretely, since the projection spaces are unique to each relation, projection matrices associated with rare relations can only be exposed to very few facts during training, resulting in poor generalization.
body_sentences.16: For common relations, a similar issue exists.
body_sentences.17: Without any restrictions on the number of projection matrices, logically related or conceptually similar relations may have distinct projection spaces, hindering the discovery, sharing, and generalization of statistical regularities.

Previously, a line of research makes use of external information such as textual relations from web-scale corpus or node features (Toutanova et al., 2015; Toutanova and Chen, 2015; Nguyen et al., 2016a), alleviating the sparsity problem.
body_sentences.19: In parallel, recent work has proposed to model regularities beyond local facts by considering multirelation paths (Garcı́a-Durán et al., 2015; Lin et al., 2015a; Shen et al., 2016).
body_sentences.20: Since the number of paths grows exponentially with its length, as a side effect, path-based models enjoy much more training cases, suffering less from the problem.
body_sentences.21: In this paper, we propose an interpretable knowledge transfer model (ITransF), which encourages the sharing of statistic regularities between the projection matrices of relations and alleviates the data sparsity problem.
body_sentences.22: At the core of ITransF is a sparse attention mechanism, which learns to compose shared concept matrices into relation-specific projection matrices, leading to a better generalization property.
body_sentences.23: Without any external resources, ITransF improves mean rank and Hits@10 on two benchmark datasets, over all previous approaches of the same kind.
body_sentences.24: In addition, the parameter sharing is clearly indicated by the learned sparse attention vectors, enabling us to interpret how knowledge transfer is carried out.
body_sentences.25: To induce the desired sparsity during optimization, we further introduce a block iterative optimization algorithm.
body_sentences.26: In summary, the contributions of this work are: (i) proposing a novel knowledge embedding model which enables knowledge transfer by learning to discover shared regularities; (ii) introducing a learning algorithm to directly optimize a sparse representation from which the knowledge transferring procedure is interpretable; (iii) showing the effectiveness of our model by outperforming baselines on two benchmark datasets for knowledge base completion task.
body_sentences.27: 2 Notation and Previous Models  Let E denote the set of entities and R denote the set of relations.
body_sentences.28: In knowledge base completion, given a training set P of triples (h, r, t) where h, t ∈ E are the head and tail entities having a relation r ∈ R, e.g., (Steve Jobs, FounderOf, Apple), we want to predict missing facts such as (Steve Jobs, Profession, Businessperson).

body_sentences.35: 3 Interpretable Knowledge Transfer    3.1 Model  As discussed above, a fundamental weakness in TransR and STransE is that they equip each relation with a set of unique projection matrices, which not only introduces more parameters but also hinders knowledge sharing.
body_sentences.36: Intuitively, many relations share some concepts with each other, although they are stored as independent symbols in KB.
body_sentences.37: For example, the relation “(somebody) won award for (some work)” and “(somebody) was nominated for (some work)” both describe a person’s high-quality work which wins an award or a nomination respectively.
body_sentences.38:
This phenomenon suggests that one relation actually represents a collection of real-world concepts, and one concept
can be shared by several relations.
body_sentences.39: Inspired by the existence of such lower-level concepts, instead of defining a unique set of projection matrices for every relation, we can alternatively define a small set of concept projection matrices and then compose them into customized projection matrices.
body_sentences.40: Effectively, the relation-dependent translation space is then reduced to the smaller concept spaces.
body_sentences.41: However, in general, we do not have prior knowledge about what concepts exist out there and how they are composed to form relations.
body_sentences.42: Therefore, in ITransF, we propose to learn this information simultaneously from data, together with all knowledge embeddings.
body_sentences.43: Following this idea, we first present the model details, then discuss the optimization techniques for training.

body_sentences.45: We let each relation select the most useful projection matrices from the tensor, where the selection is represented by an attention vector.

body_sentences.88: 3.3 Corrupted Sample Generating Method  Recall that we need to sample a negative triple (h′, r, t′) to compute hinge loss shown in Eq.
body_sentences.89: 2, given a positive triple (h, r, t) ∈ P .
body_sentences.90: The distribution of negative triple is denoted by N(h, r, t).
body_sentences.91: Previous work (Bordes et al., 2013; Lin et al., 2015b; Yang et al., 2015; Nguyen et al., 2016b) generally constructs a set of corrupted triples by replacing the head entity or tail entity with a random entity uniformly sampled from the KB.
body_sentences.92: However, uniformly sampling corrupted entities may not be optimal.
body_sentences.93: Often, the head and tail entities associated a relation can only belong to a specific domain.
body_sentences.94: When the corrupted entity comes from other domains, it is very easy for the model to induce a large energy gap between true triple and corrupted one.
body_sentences.95: As the energy gap exceeds γ, there will be no training signal from this corrupted triple.
body_sentences.96: In comparison, if the corrupted entity comes from the same domain, the task becomes harder for the model, leading to more consistent training signal.
body_sentences.97: Motivated by this observation, we propose to sample corrupted head or tail from entities in the same domain with a probability pr and from the whole entity set with probability 1 − pr.
body_sentences.98: The choice of relation-dependent probability pr is specified in Appendix A.1.
body_sentences.99: In the rest of the paper, we refer to the new proposed sampling method as ”domain sampling”.

body_sentences.103: In knowledge base completion task, we evaluate model’s performance of predicting the head entity or the tail entity given the relation and the other entity.
body_sentences.104: For example, to predict head given relation r and tail t in triple (h, r, t), we compute the energy function fr(h′, t) for each entity h′ in the knowledge base and rank all the entities according to the energy.

body_sentences.130: 4.3 Results & Analysis  The overall link prediction results1 are reported in Table 2.
body_sentences.131: Our model consistently outperforms previous models without external information on both the metrics of WN18 and FB15k.
body_sentences.132: On WN18, we even achieve a much better mean rank with comparable Hits@10 than current state-of-the-art model IRN employing external information.
body_sentences.133: We can see that path information is very helpful on FB15k and models taking advantage of path information outperform intrinsic models by a significant margin.
body_sentences.134: Indeed, a lot of facts are easier to recover with the help of multi-step inference.
body_sentences.135: For example, if we know Barack Obama is born in Honolulu, a city in the United States, then we easily know the nationality of Obama is the United States.

body_sentences.139: Performance on Rare Relations In the proposed ITransF, we design an attention mechanism to encourage knowledge sharing across different relations.
body_sentences.140: Naturally, facts associated with rare relations should benefit most from such sharing, boosting the overall performance.
body_sentences.141: To verify this hypothesis, we investigate our model’s performance on relations with different frequency.
body_sentences.142: The overall distribution of relation frequencies resembles that of word frequencies, subject to the zipf’s law.
body_sentences.143:
Since the frequencies of relations approximately follow a power distribution, their log

body_sentences.147: We can clearly see that the distributions exhibit long tails, just like the Zipf’s law for word frequency.

body_sentences.168: Model Compression A byproduct of parameter sharing mechanism employed by ITransF is a much more compact model with equal performance.
body_sentences.169: Figure 5 plots the average performance of ITransF against the number of projection matrices m, together with two baseline models.
body_sentences.170: On FB15k, when we reduce the number of matrices from 2200 to 30 (∼ 90× compression), our model performance decreases by only 0.09% on Hits@10, still outperforming STransE.
body_sentences.171: Similarly, on WN18, ITransF continues to achieve the best performance when we reduce the number of concept project matrices to 18.
